query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
1 Ora cen porta l’un de’ duri margini; 2 e ’l fummo del ruscel di sopra aduggia, 3 sì che dal foco salva l’acqua e li argini.
query.result:
**English:**
1 Now one of the hard banks carries us; 2 and the smoke from the brook darkens above, 3 so that the water and the banks are saved from the fire.
**Cornish:**
1 Wosa onen a'n gwernow kalet a'n gorra, 2 ha'n avor a'n fros a wra tewl wartha, 3 le mayth an dowr ha'n gwernow a dhef a'n tan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
4 Quali Fiamminghi tra Guizzante e Bruggia, 5 temendo ’l fiotto che ’nver’ lor s’avventa, 6 fanno lo schermo perché ’l mar si fuggia;
7 e quali Padoan lungo la Brenta, 8 per difender lor ville e lor castelli, 9 anzi che Carentana il caldo senta:
10 a tale imagine eran fatti quelli, 11 tutto che né sì alti né sì grossi, 12 qual che si fosse, lo maestro félli.
query.result:
**English:**
4 Like the Flemings between Wissant and Bruges, 5 fearing the flood that rushes towards them, 6 make a bulwark so that the sea may flee;
7 and like the Paduans along the Brenta, 8 to defend their towns and their castles, 9 before the heat is felt in Carinthia:
10 in such a likeness were those made, 11 although neither so high nor so thick, 12 whatever they were, the master made them.
**Cornish:**
4 Kepar an Flamynkyon ynter Guizzante ha Bruggia, 5 ow tynjya an fordh a wra owth tynjya wartha, 6 a wra an skreen rag an mor a alla.
7 Ha kepar an Paduanow war-hedh an Brenta, 8 rag difendya aga tre ha aga kastillow, 9 kyns na vo an tommder yn Carentana.
10 Yn aga furv ma o an re ma, 11 byttegyns na'ns o ker bras na ker tew, 12 pyth o, an mester a wra aga.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
13 Già eravam da la selva rimossi 14 tanto, ch’i’ non avrei visto dov’ era, 15 perch’ io in dietro rivolto mi fossi,
16 quando incontrammo d’anime una schiera 17 che venian lungo l’argine, e ciascuna 18 ci riguardava come suol da sera
19 guardare uno altro sotto nuova luna; 20 e sì ver’ noi aguzzavan le ciglia 21 come ’l vecchio sartor fa ne la cruna.
query.result:
**English:**
13 We had already departed from the forest 14 so far that I would not have seen where it was, 15 even if I had turned back to look,
16 when we encountered a troop of souls 17 who were coming along the bank, and each one 18 was looking at us as people are wont to do
19 in the evening when they look at each other under a new moon; 20 and they were squinting their eyes at us 21 like an old tailor does at the eye of a needle.
**Cornish:**
13 Nyns o devrewth an walsmagh 14 kemmys, na’m gwelsyn le may fo, 15 pub tra wel ow treylys vy.
16 Pan wrellasow schera a enevalow 17 ow tos orth an arg, ha pubonan 18 a wra vetha orthyn vy kepar hag yns
19 orthyn unn orth y gila orth nowydh loer; 20 ha kepar hena wra agavya aga sel 21 kepar gwrya goh a wra orth kruen an nedhel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
22 Così adocchiato da cotal famiglia, 23 fui conosciuto da un, che mi prese 24 per lo lembo e gridò: «Qual maraviglia!».
query.result:
**English:**
22 Thus scrutinized by such a company, 23 I was recognized by one, who seized me 24 by the hem and cried out: "What a marvel!"
**Cornish:**
22 Kepar hena ow tos orthys gans an teulu, 23 vyth aswon gans unn, a'm kemeras 24 orth an gwlabar ha galwas: "Pyth marvil!"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
25 E io, quando ’l suo braccio a me distese, 26 ficcaï li occhi per lo cotto aspetto, 27 sì che ’l viso abbrusciato non difese
28 la conoscenza süa al mio ’ntelletto; 29 e chinando la mano a la sua faccia, 30 rispuosi: «Siete voi qui, ser Brunetto?».
query.result:
**English:**
25 And I, when he stretched out his arm to me, 26 fixed my eyes on his baked appearance, 27 so that his scorched face did not prevent
28 my intellect from recognizing him; 29 and, reaching out my hand to his face, 30 I replied: "Is it you here, Ser Brunetto?"
**Cornish:**
25 Ha my, pan estynas aga bregh dhe'm, 26 a fickeys vy'm lagha orth aga edhom poos, 27 kepar na wra aga edhom loskys
28 ow lettya vy dhe'n vy hysbys; 29 ha ow kemeres vy'm dhorn dhe'n aga edhom, 30 vyth attebas: "A whyth why ow, Ser Brunetto?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
31 E quelli: «O figliuol mio, non ti dispiaccia 32 se Brunetto Latino un poco teco 33 ritorna ’n dietro e lascia andar la traccia».
query.result:
**English:**
31 And he: "O my son, do not be displeased 32 if Brunetto Latino turns back with you 33 for a while and lets the others continue on their way."
**Cornish:**
31 Ha henna: "O vy mab, na wra dygonis 32 mar Brunetto Latino ow treylya ganses 33 rag dhe'n vy ha ow lettya an trassa."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
34 I’ dissi lui: «Quanto posso, ven preco; 35 e se volete che con voi m’asseggia, 36 faròl, se piace a costui che vo seco».
query.result:
**English:**
34 I said to him: "As much as I can, I beg you to come; 35 and if you wish me to walk with you, 36 I will do so, if it pleases the one with whom I am going."
**Cornish:**
34 Vyth attebas dhe henna: "Kemmys ha'm gallos, vyth pegis; 35 ha mar whyth ow karas vy dhe'm kerdhes, 36 vyth wra vyth hemma, mar plij dhe henna ow mos gansan."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
37 «O figliuol», disse, «qual di questa greggia 38 s’arresta punto, giace poi cent’ anni 39 sanz’ arrostarsi quando ’l foco il feggia.
query.result:
**English:**
37 "O my son," he said, "whoever of this flock 38 stops for a moment, lies there for a hundred years 39 without being able to turn over when the fire strikes him.
**Cornish:**
37 "O vy mab," henna a leveris, "piw a'n greg owma 38 a wra sevel orth unn poynt, henna a wra gorwedh cans blydhen 39 heb gallos dhe'n aga dro dhe'n tan a wra'n tan ow fegya."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
40 Però va oltre: i’ ti verrò a’ panni; 41 e poi rigiugnerò la mia masnada, 42 che va piangendo i suoi etterni danni».
query.result:
**English:**
40 But go on: I will come to you in person; 41 and then I will rejoin my company, 42 who are weeping for their eternal losses.
**Cornish:**
40 Mes kerdh dres: vyth vyth dhe'th dhe'n pennow; 41 ha wosa henna vyth a wra'th dhe'm bagas, 42 ow pyw golla a-wela ow kolledhek traus.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
43 Io non osava scender de la strada 44 per andar par di lui; ma ’l capo chino 45 tenea com’ uom che reverente vada.
query.result:
**English:**
43 I did not dare to descend from the road 44 to go alongside him; but I kept my head bowed 45 like a man who walks respectfully.
**Cornish:**
43 Vy nyns oja dhyskynna a'n fordh 44 rag mos dhe'n keverel ganso; mes vy a via 45 kepar den ow kerdhes yn onest.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
46 El cominciò: «Qual fortuna o destino 47 anzi l’ultimo dì qua giù ti mena? 48 e chi è questi che mostra ’l cammino?».
query.result:
**English:**
46 He began: "What fortune or destiny 47 before your final day brings you here below? 48 And who is this who shows you the way?".
**Cornish:**
46 Ev a dhallathas: "Pandra po sort 47 kyns an jydh diwettha a'th gorrama? 48 Ha pandra yw hemma ow tiskwedha an fordh?".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
49 «Là sù di sopra, in la vita serena», 50 rispuos’ io lui, «mi smarri’ in una valle, 51 avanti che l’età mia fosse piena.
query.result:
**English:**
49 "Up there, in the serene life," 50 I answered him, "I lost my way in a valley, 51 before my life had reached its fullness.
**Cornish:**
49 "Wosa uhella, y'n byw paradow," 50 vy a leveris dhodho, "vy a gollais y'n avon, 51 kyns bos leun vy oadow."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
52 Pur ier mattina le volsi le spalle: 53 questi m’apparve, tornand’ ïo in quella, 54 e reducemi a ca per questo calle».
query.result:
**English:**
52 Yet only this morning I turned my back on it: 53 he appeared to me, as I was returning there, 54 and is leading me back home by this path.
**Cornish:**
52 Mes hemma myttin vy a dro's dhodho: 53 ev a dhiskwedhas dhym, vy ow thyski dhodho, 54 ha'gas owthaskylamm dhe'n fordh-ma."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
61 Ma quello ingrato popolo maligno 62 che discese di Fiesole ab antico, 63 e tiene ancor del monte e del macigno,
64 ti si farà, per tuo ben far, nimico; 65 ed è ragion, ché tra li lazzi sorbi 66 si disconvien fruttare al dolce fico.
query.result:
**English:**
61 But that ungrateful and wicked people 62 who came down from Fiesole long ago, 63 and still retain something of the mountain and the rock,
64 will make themselves your enemy because of your good deeds; 65 and it is right, because among the bitter sorbs 66 it is unfitting for the sweet fig to bear fruit.
**Cornish:**
61 Mes henna bobel drog ha dillas 62 ow tiskennas a Fiesole a-goos, 63 ha'gas ow tos ow an menydh ha'n garrek,
64 a wra dhe'n goweth, rag an pyth da ober da, 65 ha reson yw, rag ynter an sorbysow losow 66 nyns yw dhe'n figen dowr dhe'n frota.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
67 Vecchia fama nel mondo li chiama orbi; 68 gent’ è avara, invidiosa e superba: 69 dai lor costumi fa che tu ti forbi.
query.result:
**English:**
67 Ancient fame calls them blind in the world; 68 they are a miserly, envious, and proud people: 69 see to it that you cleanse yourself of their customs.
**Cornish:**
67 Koth hen yn an bys a'th gelwir orb; 68 bobel yw avarisek, gelus ha breus: 69 a'ga bosow gwreugh bos dhe'n forbi.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
70 La tua fortuna tanto onor ti serba, 71 che l’una parte e l’altra avranno fame 72 di te; ma lungi fia dal becco l’erba.
query.result:
**English:**
70 Your fortune reserves so much honor for you, 71 that both sides will be hungry 72 for you; but the grass will be far from the goat's mouth.
**Cornish:**
70 Dh'y fortin a wra serbi dhe'th kemmys onor, 71 bys teyrn ha'n nessa a wra bos kows 72 a-dro dhe'th; mes an glas a wra pell a'n gavr.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
73 Faccian le bestie fiesolane strame 74 di lor medesme, e non tocchin la pianta, 75 s’alcuna surge ancora in lor letame,
76 in cui riviva la sementa santa 77 di que’ Roman che vi rimaser quando 78 fu fatto il nido di malizia tanta».
query.result:
**English:**
73 Let the Fiesolan beasts make a dunghill 74 of themselves, and not touch the plant, 75 if any still springs up in their dung,
76 in which the holy seed of those Romans 77 who remained there when 78 the nest of so much malice was made, might revive.
**Cornish:**
73 Gwreugh an bestys Fiesolanen strame 74 a-dro dhodho, ha na dotkyn an plans, 75 mar ow surj nevra y'n aga losow,
76 y'n neb an semen sans a'n Romanes 77 ow remanis ena pan wosa gwres 78 an neyth a-vri a gallos drok."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
79 «Se fosse tutto pieno il mio dimando», 80 rispuos’ io lui, «voi non sareste ancora 81 de l’umana natura posto in bando;
82 ché ’n la mente m’è fitta, e or m’accora, 83 la cara e buona imagine paterna 84 di voi quando nel mondo ad ora ad ora
85 m’insegnavate come l’uom s’etterna: 86 e quant’ io l’abbia in grado, mentr’ io vivo 87 convien che ne la mia lingua si scerna.
query.result:
**English:**
79 “If my request were fully granted,” 80 I replied to him, “you would not yet be 81 banished from human nature;
82 for in my mind is fixed, and now grieves me, 83 the dear and good paternal image 84 of you when in the world from time to time
85 you taught me how man makes himself eternal: 86 and how much I hold it dear, while I live 87 it is fitting that my tongue should make known.
**Cornish:**
79 “Mar keffrys oedh oll ow folla’m gows,” 80 owth attebma dh’agan, “nyns eusochwi cewsel 81 a-dhia anedha denvel orth.
82 Rag yn ow mynnyth ow tos ha bos ha owth gorra, 83 anedha ker ha da bara imach an tas, 84 pan ena’n bys ena-rag-ena
85 owth tyskas dhym an fordh den a wra owth sempiterna: 86 ha kemmys owth ow karas, bys vy’m bew, 87 owth tus ow taves ow tos bos gwrys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
88 Ciò che narrate di mio corso scrivo, 89 e serbolo a chiosar con altro testo 90 a donna che saprà, s’a lei arrivo.
query.result:
**English:**
88 What you relate of my course I write down, 89 and I keep it to seal with another text 90 for a lady who will know, if I reach her.
**Cornish:**
88 An traethas a wra a’m kors ow skrifav, 89 ha’m gorra dhe dhalek gans testen aral 90 dhe’n venen a wra gows, mar keffrys owth karas.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
91 Tanto vogl’ io che vi sia manifesto, 92 pur che mia coscïenza non mi garra, 93 ch’a la Fortuna, come vuol, son presto.
query.result:
**English:**
91 So much do I want you to know, 92 as long as my conscience does not deceive me, 93 that to Fortune, as she wills, I am ready.
**Cornish:**
91 Kemmys a vynnav dhyw bos gwrys, 92 byttegens na gorra ow koskians ow gorra, 93 dhe dhe’n Fortyun, dell yw karas, owth prest.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
94 Non è nuova a li orecchi miei tal arra: 95 però giri Fortuna la sua rota 96 come le piace, e ’l villan la sua marra».
query.result:
**English:**
94 Such a speech is not new to my ears: 95 therefore let Fortune turn her wheel 96 as she pleases, and the peasant his hoe.
**Cornish:**
94 Nyns yw nowyth dhe’m klevow henna: 95 rag henna, le Fortyun tro’y hwil 96 dell yw karas, ha’n vilan y var.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
97 Lo mio maestro allora in su la gota 98 destra si volse in dietro e riguardommi; 99 poi disse: «Bene ascolta chi la nota».
query.result:
**English:**
97 My master then on his right 98 cheek turned back and looked at me; 99 then he said: “He who notes it listens well.”
**Cornish:**
97 Ow mester ena-gwra ena’n wonn dhe dhe 98 dhelergh owth tro’y dhelergh ha’m selwas; 99 wosa henna, owth leveris: “Owth klev an pyw ow nota.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
100 Né per tanto di men parlando vommi 101 con ser Brunetto, e dimando chi sono 102 li suoi compagni più noti e più sommi.
query.result:
**English:**
100 Nevertheless, I continue speaking 101 with Ser Brunetto, and I ask who are 102 his most famous and greatest companions.
**Cornish:**
100 Mes nyns yw rag henna owth gorra ow kows 101 gans Ser Brunetto, ha’m gorra pyw yw 102 y gompagnons moyha kenedhla ha moyha uhella.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
103 Ed elli a me: «Saper d’alcuno è buono; 104 de li altri fia laudabile tacerci, 105 ché ’l tempo saria corto a tanto suono.
query.result:
**English:**
103 And he said to me: "To know of some is good; 104 of the others it would be praiseworthy to be silent, 105 for time would be short for so much sound.
**Cornish:**
103 Ha henna dhymm: "Godhes dhe dhyso yw da; 104 a'y gila yw gwella tavos, 105 rag an amser a vydh byr pur an son na."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
106 In somma sappi che tutti fur cherci 107 e litterati grandi e di gran fama, 108 d’un peccato medesmo al mondo lerci.
query.result:
**English:**
106 In short, know that all of them were sought out, 107 and great scholars and of great fame, 108 stained in the world by the same sin.
**Cornish:**
106 Yn fyrra godhes bos vyth olys hwilas, 107 ha dyskoryon meur ha a vri gerens, 108 gans halhes gans an pechod keth yw lerghes.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
109 Priscian sen va con quella turba grama, 110 e Francesco d’Accorso anche; e vedervi, 111 s’avessi avuto di tal tigna brama,
112 colui potei che dal servo de’ servi 113 fu trasmutato d’Arno in Bacchiglione, 114 dove lasciò li mal protesi nervi.
query.result:
**English:**
109 Priscian goes with that wretched throng, 110 and Francesco d’Accorso also; and to see them, 111 if you had had such a craving,
112 you could have seen the one who by the servant of servants 113 was transferred from the Arno to the Bacchiglione, 114 where he left his sinews badly stretched.
**Cornish:**
109 Priscian a wra yn-mes a'y dorf vil, 110 ha Frances d’Accorso ynwedh; ha'gas gweles, 111 mar esa dhe dhyso dhe'n fordh na,
112 ty a alla dhe'n neb a veu gans an servas a'y servas 113 gwrysys a'n Arno dhe'n Bacchiglione, 114 le may hy esa dhe'n nervow drog dhysprysys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
115 Di più direi; ma ’l venire e ’l sermone 116 più lungo esser non può, però ch’i’ veggio 117 là surger nuovo fummo del sabbione.
query.result:
**English:**
115 I would say more; but the coming and the discourse 116 cannot be longer, because I see 117 new smoke rising there from the sand.
**Cornish:**
115 Mebyon moy a leveraf; mes an mos ha'n preder 116 nyns yw possybyl moy es; rag wovyn 117 nowydh fum ow tos owth an sabon.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
118 Gente vien con la quale esser non deggio. 119 Sieti raccomandato il mio Tesoro, 120 nel qual io vivo ancora, e più non cheggio».
query.result:
**English:**
118 People are coming with whom I must not be. 119 May my Treasure be commended to you, 120 in which I still live, and I ask no more.
**Cornish:**
118 Dus a dheus gans an dus na drefen vyth. 119 Bew commendys dhe'n Tresor vy, 120 yn neb ow pyw vyth byw, ha nyns desyraf moy.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
121 Poi si rivolse, e parve di coloro 122 che corrono a Verona il drappo verde 123 per la campagna; e parve di costoro
124 quelli che vince, non colui che perde.
query.result:
**English:**
121 Then he turned and seemed like one of those 122 who run at Verona for the green cloth 123 across the plain; and he seemed of these
124 the one who wins, not the one who loses.
**Cornish:**
121 Wosa henna ev a droas, ha ev a welas 122 avel an reydh yn Verona rag an drapp gwer 123 a-dreus an mayn; ha ev a welas a'n reydh na
124 an neb a wayny, nyns an neb a goll.
